texts.ru: Фотима сотрудничает с МикроИнвест уже 4 года. За это время в ее жизни было много перемен. За счет займа, который она целенаправленно оборачивала она смогла прикупить приданное и выдать замуж свою дочь. Постоянной работы она не нашла и занятие предпринимательством для нее основной источник дохода. Фотиме 46 лет, у нее 3 детей.  Продает мелкие товары: носки платки носовые, мелкую бижутерию и тп. Фотима собирается немного расширить свой бизнес, и поэтому подала заявку на займ.
texts.en:
Fotima has been working with MicroInvest for four years. During this time there were a lot of changes in her life. Because of the loans she took which she purposefully turned over she was able to buy a dowry and have a wedding for her daughter. She has not found a permanent job and her business is the main source of income for her. Fotima is 46 years old, she has three children. She sells small items: socks, handkerchiefs, small jewelry and etc. Fotima plans to expand her business a little and this is why she applied for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Abdurazzok

texts.ru: Абдураззок недавно приехал из заработков с России. Экономический кризис коснулся его места работы там и поэтому он решил вернуться. Здесь в Исфаре  он раньше занимался куплей продажей сухофруктов и сейчас решил вновь возобновить этот бизнес. Абдураззоку 34 года, женат имеет 3 детей. Он собирается получить займ и употребить его на расширение бизнеса.
texts.en:
Abdurazzok recently returned from working in Russia. His position was eliminated due to the economic crisis so he decided to move back to Tajikistan. He had sold dried fruit in Isfara in the past, and he decided to re-enter that business. Abdurazzok is 34 years old, married, and has three children. He plans to obtain a loan to use in expanding his business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Salima

texts.ru: В июне у Салимы закончился прежний кредит от КИВА. За это время в ее жизни произошли приятные перемены. Ее старшая дочь, которая помогала Салиме в ее бизнесе недавно вышла замуж (на фото). Это произошло благодаря трудолюбию Салимы, которая не бросила заниматься бизнесом, несмотря на все трудности.  Сейчас Салима вместе со своим братом в дополнение к своему основному бизнесу – купле продажи фруктов, стала заниматься куплей продажей мелкого рогатого скота. Для восполнения недостатка денежных средств решила получить займ.
texts.en:
In June, Salima’s previous KIVA loan ended. Since that time positive changes happened in her life. Her eldest daughter, who helped Salima in her business, recently got married (she is in the photo). This occurred due to Salima’s industriousness; she did not stop working on her business despite all the difficulties. Today in addition to her main business - purchasing and selling fruit - Salima together with her brother has started to purchase and sell small livestock. She decided to take out a loan to fill her shortage of funds.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Abduvakkos

texts.ru: Абдуваккос работает сторожем в местном отделении сберегательного банка. Режим работы там 1 день работа, 2 дня выходных. Поэтому кроме основной работы у Абдуваккоса остается много свободного времени и поэтому он также занимается перевозкой людей на своей собственной машине. А по базарным дням занимается куплей продажей сухофруктов на местном рынке. Все эти виды деятельности помогают ему покрывать расходы его семьи. Абдуваккосу 56 лет, женат, имеет 2 детей. Абдуваккос решил подать заявку на займ и собирается расширить куплю продажу сухофруктов.
texts.en:
Abduvakkos works as a security guard at the local bank branch. The work schedule there is to work 1 day and then have 2 days off. Because of this Abduvakkos has a lot of free time left after he works his main job and thus he also transports people in his personal vehicle. On market days he purchases and sells dried fruits at the local market. All of these activities help him to cover family expenditures. Abduvakkos is 56 years old, he is married and has 2 children. Abduvakkos decided to apply for a loan and plans to expand his dried fruit business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Faauuga

texts.en:
Faauuga F., 26, is married with 3 children. She has 5 years of experience in the pancake and pork bun business. She sells to the general public 5 days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala (58 USD). SPBD loans are Faauuga’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

Faauuga plans to use the loan to purchase basins, fryer, flour, sugar, yeast, containers, onions, lamp flaps, oil, soya sauce and garlic onions.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her pancake and pork bun business

loans.name: Suong

texts.en:
Suong H., age 48, has a six-member family and lives in Banteay Meanchey Province. The couple has four children; three of them are single and the other is married and lives independently.

He owns a car that he uses to provide a taxi service. Almost all of his clients are passers-by, tourists, and merchants. In addition to his taxi service, he also uses his car to transport fruit to the market for his wife to sell. The family can generate an income of approximately $15 per day to manage their family's living expenses.

Because the business of selling fruit is a profitable for the family, Suong H. is looking for a loan to use as capital to increase his stock of fruit for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To increase stocks of fruit

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Mrs. Leonora S. has been a loyal member of PMPC since 2005. She is so thankful to PMPC for the trust that has accorded to her. She is now asking for a loan of PHP 20,000.

She works with her husband and her son to select "bangus" (milkfish) fingerlings. The couple receive from their children a monthly allowance to support their daily needs. Recently, they expanded their house and made a new set of "sodsod" fishing accessories.

Leonora now cuddles their “apo” (grandchildren) who live with them, but never gets tired of continuing their everyday undertakings.

loans.use: To buy stocks of  "bangus" (milkfish) fingerlings

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Ms. Agustina B. is a single mother, 59 years old, with one child. She started her business with a small sari-sari (variety) store located in front of Century Ice Plant and Paglaum MPC. She is a pioneering member of the Masidlakon Center under the Microfinance PDP-LP program of Paglaum Coop. Good credit standing has justified Agustina's continued qualification for higher loan amounts.

Because her mini-grocery can already provide for the family's daily needs, Agustina borrowed money to finance the education of her son, who is now working abroad.

"I am very grateful to Paglaum because we were able to meet the family's needs, even the education of my child. I cannot imagine my child going to college had I not been a member of Paglaum," she said. Agustina is happy with what she is getting from her little store and the support of PMPC. She is now venturing into the ready-to-wear (RTW) business.

loans.use: To buy stocks of RTW's (ready-to-wear) clothing

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina  M. is a 41-year-old widowed mother of seven.  Her sons: Joey, Rocky and Jeppy, are helping her support the family. Her eldest son, Joey, is driving their tricycle (rickshaw) for hire.  Gina is making puto (a cake made of rice) as their daily source of income. She is financing the education of four kids: two in secondary school and two in elementary school. 

She applied for this loan to buy assorted ingredients for her rice cakes such as rice, sugar, baking powder, oil, and cheese. She wants to purchase these items in bulk in order to get a better price at the market. She hopes to save enough money to sustain her business and keep her orders up. She dreams of having a separate work area from her house in the future.

loans.use: To buy assorted ingredients for puto (rice cake)

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S. is 57 years old and a resident of Banteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia, where she runs a small restaurant. She normally sells her daily diet to the people of her neighborhood and passers-by across the street. She can make around $15 a day to support her family's needs.

She is a divorced mother of eight children. One of her children is married and lives separately. The others are students who help her with her business when they are not learning. Two of her children are employed in Phnom Penh. The oldest child is a trader and the second is a private teacher.

Because Mrs. S. needs to satisfy her customer's requirements, she would like to ask for a loan to buy necessary ingredients and to improve her workshop.

loans.use: To buy necessary ingredients and to improve her workshop

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Mrs. Carmelita A. is 52 years of age. She is married and has two children. She signed up for her Paglaum membership because she is attracted to the various programs and services that the cooperative has offered.

She runs a sari-sari (variety) store and she sells fruit. Despite going through a lot of challenges in her business pursuits, Carmelita believes in hard work. She said that Paglaum is true to its word in bringing hope to its members and potential members. With the wide array of programs and services, the members can find it all with Paglaum. She dreams of sending all of her children to college.

loans.use: To buy fruit in addition to sari-sari store stocks

loans.name: Mayeth

texts.en:
Mayeth F. is a 21 year-old mother of two, and her partner Fritz is a laborer. The couple works very hard to support the needs of the family. Mayeth joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) two years ago and used a previous loan to buy and sell dried fish.  

She is now requesting a new loan to start a new venture, buying fancy jewelry for resale.  Maryeth hopes to sell even more expensive jewelry in the future and dreams of growing her enterprise to save enough money for her children’s future and to have a stall in the market where she can display her wares.

loans.use: To buy assorted jewelries.

loans.name: Lucille

texts.en:
Mrs. Lucille C. is 26 years old and married. Her husband is a fisherman. They are blessed with two children and live in Biasong, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental.

She became a member of PDP-LP's microfinance program in 2007 and she already borrowed and repaid three regular loans for her projects. Her loans were used to supply their fishing business. Their project is doing well and continues to progress and it's a big help to them with their day-to-day needs.

She hopes that through the help of Paglaum and Kiva, all of their children can finish their studies. They hope to live a comfortable life with the savings from their business.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing net and repair their fishing boat

loans.name: Glory

texts.en:
Glory L. is a 26 year-old mother of three. Her eldest daughter, Lowela Feliz, is five years old, her second son, King Lowel, is two years old, and Lowyne  Jame is a year old. They are the inspiration for Glory and her husband to survive the challenges of life. 

Despite the economic crisis they are experiencing, both are very grateful to have the opportunity to request this loan to start a new business. The money will to be used to buy assorted foods for her variety store.  Glory hopes that through her small initial capital she will be able to sustain the business and not only earn income but also serve her neighbors. She aspires to send her children to university.

loans.use: To buy assorted foods for her variety store.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok K., age 26, has been farming for a long time. She owns farmland that she inherited from her grandmother to grow crops. She is married and has three young children who are enrolled in school. Her husband helps her in the farming business.

K. wants a loan to buy a cow and raise its offspring. The family lives in Pursat Province.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Norma Alicia

texts.es: Norma Alicia L. D. G. D. 39 años D. edad resiD. en Ilopango junto a sus tres hijos menores D. edad y su esposo el cual trabaja como motorista D. transporte público. Norma es costurera, y realiza su trabajo en su casa, ella cose para personas D. la zona y se esfuerza mucho para poder entregar un excelente trabajo a sus clientes D. manera que estos sean fieles a ella. Norma solícita un préstamo para poder comprar materia prima como hilos, agujas entre otros materiales para la costura. D. esta manera ella logra contribuir junto a su esposo para todos los gastos D. la familia, y a través D. este préstamo espera mejorar su negocio e incrementar sus ventas, ya que es por medio D. este trabajo por el cual pueD. solventar junto a su esposo todas las necesidades básicas del hogar.
texts.en:
Norma Alicia G. D. L. is 39 years old and resides in Ilopango along with her three young children and her husband who works as public transportation driver. Norma is a seamstress and does her work from home. She sews for people in her neighborhood and tries hard to be able to deliver an excellent job to her clients so that they remain loyal customers. Norma is requesting a loan so that she can buy materials such as thread and needles and other materials for sewing. This way she is able to contribute, along with her husband, to the family expenses. Through this loan she hopes to improve her business and increase her sales since it is through this work that she and her husband can pay for the basic needs of the household.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials.

loans.name: Filicidad

texts.en:
Mrs. Filicidad S., a 60-year-old mother of four children, sells cosmetic products and ready-to-wear items on a commission basis.  Gratified that she was able to send all of her children to school and that they have subsequently established their own families and careers, Filicidad now sells her products during weekly center meetings. 
	
She is very thankful for the loan assistance provided to her by Paglaum.

loans.use: To purchase ready-to-wear items and cosmetic products.

loans.name: Sakhy Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Latefa is the group leader of Sakhy M. group. There are two members in this group. They want to take loans for their respective businesses.

Sakhy M. wants a loan for his carpet weaving business. He wants to buy necessary materials for his shop. Latefa wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She will use the loan to buy two new machines.

With this loan they will grow their businesses, support their families and provide a better future for them. They are really happy with this process in their home country of Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy new machines for a tailoring business

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie P. is a 32-year-old mother of six. Her husband Jason is a fisherman.  She buys and resells fish and raises chickens to help support the family. She applied for this loan to support her current fish vending business, and some of her loan will be used to buy fishing gear.  She joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) to apply for more loans in the future to supplement her new venture. She hopes to get a stall in the market to sell greater volumes of fish which would help to increase her income. She dreams of sending her children to a university.

loans.use: To grow her fish vending business and to buy fishing gear.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Santos Liduvina

texts.es: Santos Liduvina M. de 39 años de edad, reside en Ilopango junto a sus dos hijos, uno de 20 años y el menor de 17 años de edad, y su esposo el cual trabaja como comerciante. Santos Liduvina posee una tienda de productos perecederos, los cuales los comercializa en su propia casa, debido a que en el lugar que vive es muy transitado vende mucho durante el día. Es por ello que solicita un préstamo, a través del cual pueda comprar más productos de primera necesidad, ya que es un negocio muy rentable para ella, a través del cual obtiene ganancias las cuales contribuyen a que pueda brindarles estudio a sus hijo y también pueda junta a su esposo solventar todos los gastos del hogar, ya que es por medio de este negocio donde logran obtener mayores ingresos, es por esto que Santos Liduvina desea invertir más en su tienda, lo cual lo puede lograr a través de dicho préstamo.
texts.en:
Santos Liduvina M. is 39 years old and lives in Ilopango with her two sons, one who is 20 years old, another who is under 17 years old, and her husband who works as a trader. Santos Liduvina has a grocery store and sells the products from her home. Because her home is in an high-traveled area, she sells a lot during the day. She is requesting a loan so that she can buy more essential goods. This is a very profitable business for her and provides her with profits that contribute to her sons' education and also allow her to contribute to the household expenses. It is through this business that Santos and her husband obtain greater income which is why she wants to invest more in her store which she can achieve through this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more products for grocery store.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok R. is a 26 year old vegetable grower. She can plant twice a year and normally sells her produces to buyers every two months. To help the family's food needs a little more, her husband drives a motor taxi. The young couple has only one young child who is not enrolled in school.

Sok R.'s husband is facing a problem that his motor breaks. They have decided to apply for a loan to repair their old motorbike.

loans.use: To repair her husband's old motorbike.

loans.name: Dionesia

texts.en:
Mrs. Dionesia D. is 63 years old and married to Eufemio D., a fisherman. They are blessed with six children. The couple is so very thankful to Paglaum. One of their children is a beneficiary of Paglaum Community Development Foundation Incorporated, the mother organization of the cooperative that supports the educational needs of their students.

Recently, Dionesia started a new business. She enjoys making "longganisa" (processed meat) using the capital she got from Paglaum. She packs the longganisa and keeps it refrigerated.

She is a good member and has religiously made her required payments during the center meetings. Her business is on-going and she hopes to succeed in her new business venture.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food production

loans.name: Silvia Elizabeth

texts.es: Silvia Elizabeth P. V. de 42 años de edad, reside en Ilopango junto a su esposo y dos hijas, la mayor de 23 años y la menor de 6 años, y con una nieta de 18 meses de edad. Ella se dedica a fabricar trajes para señoras, los cuales los distribuye en el oriente del país. Silvia Elizabeth solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda obtener el capital necesario para invertir en su negocio comprando materia prima para fabricar más vestidos, de esta manera ella anhela incrementar sus ventas, y así poder brindarles todo lo necesario a su familia, ya que por medio de su negocio es como logran obtener las mayores ganancias. Es así como Silvia desea poder mejorar su negocio y así mismo mejorar la estabilidad económica de su familia, brindando mayor variedad de vestidos y obteniendo mayores ganancias de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Silvia Elizabeth P. V. is 42 years old and lives in Ilopango with her husband and two daughters, a 23 year old and a 6 year old, and a granddaughter who is 18 months old. She manufactures womens' dresses which she distributes in the eastern part of the country. Silvia Elizabeth requests a loan which she will use as capital to invest in her business by purchasing material to make more dresses. This way she hopes to increase her sales and thus allow her to provide everything necessary for her family since her business is what allows them to obtain greater income. By offering a greater variety of clothes and obtaining more profits from her customers, Silvia hopes to improve her business and at the same time improve the economic stability of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make dresses.

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
Mrs. Lam S. and her husband have been working as local crop cultivators for more than ten years. She is 48 and a good mother of four children, who still live in the family home. One of her children is employed. The couple works hard at their farm business activities every day to make an income to meet their children's needs.

The family faces difficulty with transportation during mature crop season. Lam S. is looking for a loan in order to buy an ox-cart so she can use it to transport her crops.

loans.use: To buy an ox-cart.

loans.name: Taumailuma

texts.en: Taumailuma L., 45, is married with 6 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the flea market business. She sells to the public 6 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about US $104).  SPBD loans are Taumailuma’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To improve her flea market business

loans.name: Pese

texts.en: Pese P., 52, is married with 6 children.  She has 3 years experience in the plantation business.  She sells to the village and the public 6 days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 tala (WST).  SPBD loans are Pese’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To pay her children’s school fees and acquire more equipment for her plantation.

loans.name: Merle

texts.en:
Merle F. is a 47 year-old mother of four. Her husband Angel is a fisherman. The family live in a village along the sea of San Jose, Antique, the capital town of the province. Her present business is a variety store, established using her previous loans from ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.). The income from her store and her monthly honorarium for being a councilor in the village are not enough to support the needs of her family, especially the education expenses of her two children in college and one in high school. 

Mergelyn, her eldest daughter, helped her in managing their grocery store. She applied for this loan to buy a brand new motorized fishing boat for her husband. She hopes that through her proposed business she will be able to sell a large volume of fish, enabling her to save for the expansion of her venture. She dreams of expanding her fishing boat in the future. She also wants to save money for the education of her children and to improve their house.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorized fishing boat

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en: Lagi P., 30, is married with no children.  She has 3 years of experience in the Pork Cakes business. She sells to school children, teachers, and village people 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (about US $52).  SPBD loans are Lagi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her husband is a shopkeeper and he runs the shop.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her Pork Cake store

loans.name: Uli

texts.en: Uli T., 39, is a widow with 5 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the general store business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about US $104).  SPBD loans are Uli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her general store

loans.name: Wajeya Group

texts.en:
Wajeya is the group leader of this group, which has three members. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses.

Wajeya and Yasamyn want a loan to buy necessary materials for their tailoring businesses. Fowzya wants to take a loan for her general store. She is very happy with this loan in Afghanistan. They say that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for their businesses.

loans.name: Magalelei

texts.en:
Magalelei O., 42, is married with 8 children. Her husband is a fisherman and he also does the farming.

Magalelei has five years of experience in the taro, banana and taamu business. She sells to the village people and public one day a week. This is her second request for 1500 with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala. 

SPBD loans are Magalelei's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also use some of the loan for school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay her kid’s school fees and purchase more tools and fertilizers for the plantation.

loans.name: Lole

texts.en:
Lole L., 38, is married with 8 children. She has 4 years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. This is her first loan with SPBD. She will use the loan to purchase rice, flour, sugar, onions, salt, seasoning oil, laundry soap and powder, beverages, snacks like bongos twities, chilly chocs, ice pops, ice cream and lollies to sell. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 291 Tala.

SPBD loans are Lole's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase rice, flour, sugar, onions, salt, seasoning oil, laundry soap and powder, beverages, and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Afulilo

texts.en:
Afulilo L., 45, is married with 7 children. She has five years of experience in the taro business. She sells to the village people and public two days a week. This loan of 1100 Tala is her second loan with SPBD; she paid off her first loan of 750 Tala. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala. 

SPBD loans are Afulilo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment to work her plantation, and timber and iron roofing for house repairs.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena S. is a 54 year-old mother of five. Her husband is a farmer who works a hectare of land owned by his parents. Magdalena raises pigs and ducks to help support their family. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) two years ago to get capital to finance inputs needed by their farm. 

She is applying for this loan to buy inputs such as fertilizers and chemicals. She wants to purchase them in advance in order to get a lesser price, because when she buys them during the planting season the price is much higher. 

She also wants to avoid borrowing from her neighbors, for sometimes they tend to borrow money from usurious lenders to be paid back during harvest in the form of rice grains. The couple wants to save their production to obtain a higher price during disposal of their harvest, and to save for their family's food consumption during the year. 

Magdalena dreams of owning land in the future through her loans with KIVA and ASHI.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and chemicals.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luafa

texts.en:
Luafa S., 52, is married with four children. She has ten years of experience in the taro and taamu business. She sells to the village people and public three days per week. She paid off her first loan of 750 tala and this loan of 1500 tala is her second loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala. 

SPBD loans are Luafa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Pay for her kids' school fees and purchase timber, iron roofing and nails for house repairs.

loans.name: Asenati

texts.en:
Asenati M., 34, is married with 3 children. She has five years of experience in the ice cake and cigarette business. She sells to the village people and public seven days per week. This is her second loan for 1500 with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala.  Asenati plans to renovate her home with this loan.

SPBD loans are Asenati's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase timber, cement, paint, tools, nails, and iron roofing to renovate her home.

loans.name: Sulu

texts.en: Sulu M., 48, is married with 9 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the Taro plantation business. She sells to the village people, especially the public, 3 days per week.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala (about US $21).  SPBD loans are Sulu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Sulu plans to use this money to pay for her children's school fees, things needed to improve her plantation, and house repairs.

loans.use: For school fees, farming supplies, and house repairs

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth V. is a 56 year-old mother of five. Her husband is a farmer. They live in a village situated in the middle of the vast rice land of San Jose, Antique, the capital town of the province. Two of her children got married after their secondary education. The couple has no capacity to send the two to college because their income is not enough to support it. 

However, when she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) she got capital to start a new venture. Soon after, she was able to send two of her children to secondary school and one to elementary school, hoping to support them until college. She applied for this loan to buy assorted foods for her variety store to sustain its operation and to keep her regular customers. She dreams of saving enough money to get a stall in the market.

loans.use: To buy assorted foods for her variety store

loans.name: Teutele

texts.en: Teutele P. M., 29, is married with 3 children. She has five years of experience in the traditional Samoan printing of fabric, called elei. She sells to the village people and also the public six days per week. This is her second loan for 1500 with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala. Teutele plans to do some home renovations with this money and to purchase items she needs to improve her business. SPBD loans are Teutele's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase cement, timber, iron roofing for home repairs.

loans.name: Lole

texts.en:
Lole F., 57, is married with seven children. She has two years of experience in the baking business. She sells to the village people and to the public five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (approximately 70 USD).

She has one previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Lole’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Lole plans to use this money to improve her business and make repairs to her home.

loans.use: To purchase cement, nails, paint and timber to repair her house and ingredients for her baking business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok N., 57, has been planting a variety of crops on her farmland located in Pursat Province for years. She grows rice, cabbages, morning glory, and cucumbers, and she will sell these to the buyers when they are matured. Besides her farm work, she is also a good homemaker who cooks tasty food and cares for the children. She is married to Horn, 60, who works with her in the business operation. She has 10 children and seven of them are married and live independently.

In the past, the family always hired a cow for their farming business and they now hope to own a cow, but they lack the money to make that possible. Therefore, Sok N. is looking for a loan to be able to buy a cow. (Mrs. N.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Nuridin

texts.en:
D. Nuridin is 25 years old. He is selling DVD disks. He orders the delivery of the disks from Russia and tries to have all new movies, concerts of the popular actors, singers and others. He is also providing computer services such as audio editing of video tapes and disks with records of his clients' family events. Nuridin tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work so he can satisfy the demands and requirements of the customers. The business is successful in generating a good income for his family. Today he requests $400 US Dollars. He is planning to purchase a lot of DVD disks to increase the range of his goods for sale. Nuridin thanks all who are supporting him and promises to be accurate in loan payment.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of DVD disks

loans.name: Gufron

texts.en:
T. Gufron is a very hard working and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Khujand, Tajikistan. He is married and has two children. Gufron works in the central city market selling kid’s clothing, table-cloth, coverlet and towels. His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for 2 years. Once a month he travels to the neighboring city Istaravshan to purchase new goods. When he is absent, his wife (pictured) helps him with the business.

Gufron likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Gufron would like to ask for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase new inventory. We believe Gufron‘s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of the growth of Gufron’s business.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and for it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.


IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing to sell.

loans.name: Paok

texts.en: Almost 75 % of Cambodians earn their living as farmers, one of whom is 48-year-old Mrs. Paok N. of Pursat Province. This mother of four children, all students, is assisted by her husband in growing a variety of crops and is now requesting a loan to purchase a cow and some piglets for her enterprise.

loans.use: To buy a cow and piglets.

loans.name: Komiljon

texts.en:
Komiljon T. is 23 years old. He is not married. Due to his family’s financial situation, Komiljon did not have many opportunities to study at the University. That’s why after finishing the school he tried to become independent and find a way of earning money in order to help his parents with family expenses. Since 2007, Komiljon has supported his family through his efforts. During this time he has tried various types of activities. Finally, a year ago he started his own business selling cell phones. Komiljon believes that this business is profitable and the generated income allows him to support his family. Currently, his business is doing well, but Komiljon needs to increase the stock of his goods in order to serve the demands of his clientele. For this purpose he requests US $400. Komiljon is grateful to all supporting him and promises to repay the loan promptly.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Expand cell phone store inventory

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina E. is a 45-year-old mother of three. Her husband Reynaldo is a tuba gatherer (tuba means coconut wine). She raises chickens and sells fish to help support the needs of the family. She applied for this loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle to be used in selling fish in the neighboring village. They hope to sell fish in volume to increase their income. Her son Renaldo will help his father in managing their proposed business.

Josefina is very grateful for the opportunities she got by joining ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), which supports her in all the dreams she has. She's proud to be one of the empowered women of today. She is very happy to be able to send her youngest daughter to college and earn a degree in order to get a better job.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for fish vending

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.en: Mamlakat B., 39, married with three children, lives in Khhujand where she has sold a good assortment of menswear and shoes procured from Istaravshan for the past four years.  She is now requesting a loan of 1200 STJ for one month to replenish her stock and to import the new seasonal wares.  Mamlakat thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new seasonal wares.

loans.name: Otunoi

texts.en:
M. Otunoi first applied for a business support loan from MicroInvest in 2008. Thanks to her previous loans, she has been able to improve and normalize her existing business in terms of hard market competition. Otunoi trades in children's, men's, and women's shoes, which she obtains from straight suppliers. Otunoi has been trading in shoes for 5 years and she is experienced in the business.

Otunoi has applied to Kiva for a business support loan of 1400 STJ for 1 month to import seasonal goods. She thanks Kiva for the small business support and development.

loans.use: To import seasonal goods

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en: O. Mavjuda lives in Khujand; she is married with a little child. Mavjuda trades in men's jackets in the local bazaar. She has been engaged in this business for 15 years, so she knows  the Tajik market specials well. Mavjuda has a good assortment of merchandise and repeat customers. She has applied to Kiva for a business development loan of 1000 STJ for 1 month to increase her merchandise assortment and turnover.

loans.use: To buy additional jackets to sell

loans.name: Mong

texts.en:
Mong K., 59, owns a medium grocery store next to her house, where she sells different kinds of groceries, including cooked ingredients, snacks, and soft drinks. Most of her clients are villagers who live near her house. She is 59 years old and the mother of three children who are single and employed. They are garment workers in the garment industry. Her husband assists her in selling groceries.

Recently, K. sold all her wares from her store. Therefore, she needs to borrow $500 in order to restock her grocery inventory for sale.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Batzaya

texts.en:
Batzaya S. lives with his wife and two daughters, both students in a local high school, in Arhanghay Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces.  Batzaya learned how to drive and fix cars at an early age and now owns a small car repair shop. Throughout the day, Batzaya repairs and changes the oil in cars and motorcycles while his wife washes their clients’ vehicles.  He also sells various car accessories and parts, and in the evening drives a cab to earn extra income. 

Batzaya is a very hardworking entrepreneur who is now requesting a loan to purchase more car accessories and a larger stock of car oil.

loans.use: To purchase more car accessories and a larger stock of car oil.

loans.name: Nurinisso

texts.en:
S. Nurinisso is married with 4 children and she lives in Khujand. Nurinisso has been selling men's wear in the local bazaar for 10 years. She brings the assortment from Istarvshn and she sells at lower prices than the bazaar prices because she brings in the assortment for herself.

Nurinisso is applying to KIVA with the request for a business support loan of 1400 STJ for 1 month for importing new seasonal wear that will permit her to increase the business turnover and business terms. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: importing new seasonal wear

loans.name: Bayantsatsral

texts.en:
Bayantsatsral R. lives with his wife and three teenage children in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His children go to local public schools. Bayantsatsral and his wife run a small retail stall for women and men's clothing and shoes at the local market.

Bayantsatsral started the retail business in 2005 by selling clothes and shoes imported from Ereen, China, a border town with Mongolia. While he goes to Ereen to purchase new inventory, his wife manages the stall. Their business capital has increased from 700,000 MNT to 2,000,000 MNT ($1 MNT=1,500 MNT). Bayantsatsral requests a loan to purchase more clothes from Ereen to increase his business inventory. Bayartsatsral and his wife hope to be able to afford university education for all their children.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Chinzorig

texts.en:
Chinzorig P. is a single mother and lives with her only son in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Chinzorig was trained as a seamstress. She started a small business in 2001 sewing cotton seat covers for cars in her town. Difficult economic times and a decline in car ownership caused her to switch to the food service industry, opening a small fast food restaurant. The food service business did not fare very well either.

Now the number of cars in the town has increased due to economic growth during the last five years. Chinzorig re-launched her sewing business recently to meet the increasing demand for customized seat covers. Her sewing business is now doing well and she is the sole provider of customized seat covers in town. She requests a loan to purchase a new sewing machine to replace her old one and more cotton cloth.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine to replace her old one

loans.name: Chhoem's Group

texts.en:
This small loan group is made up of three people; Mrs. P. is the team leader. P., age 51, works as cleaning staff in the garment industry. She gets a specific salary of US$ 80 a month to manage her family's daily expenses. She is married with six children; two of them are married and live separately. Her four single children are employed as sewing workers in a garment factory. Her husband is a motorbike taxi driver. The family faces difficulty with transportation to work because the workplaces are located far from their home. Therefore, P. is applying for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her family to ride to work.

The other two borrowers are:

Ren S., a garment worker seeking a loan to replace her old motorbike to ride to work; and

Oun S., a worker in the garment industry who requests a loan to run a grocery store.

The borrowers live in KonTok Commune, in Kandal Province.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Dakan (Le Destin) Group

texts.fr:
Dakan est un regroupement de cinq femmes du  village de Kimparana (préfecture de San région de Ségou) qui, unies par des liens de parenté et  de voisinage, ont en moyenne 42 ans,  6  enfants et vivent dans des foyers traditionnels élargis
Elles mènent différentes activités parmi lesquelles nous allons retenir essentiellement, la vente de produits de beauté et des fruits et légumes.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125.000 FCFA pour le cinquième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe.) Tous les précédents prêts ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Ce présent prêt servira à acheter une importante quantité de produits cosmétiques et des chargements de charrettes en fruits et légumes.
Les femmes du groupe Dakan se procurent de leurs marchandises à Bamako (la capitale de la république du MALI) et à Kimparana et effectuent leurs ventes dans les marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants à San et de Kimparana en détail au comptant et à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser  chacune un bénéfice de 140.000 FCFA au cours du cycle qui servira, en  plus du  remboursement du prêt à  faire face aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Dakan is a group of five women of the village of Kimparana (San prefecture, Ségou region) who are united by ties of kinship and community. They average 42 years of age and 6 children each and live in traditional extended households. The women do different work, among them we're going to retain essentially the sale of beauty products and of fruit and vegetables.

To expand their businesses, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program three years ago. Loan amounts have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan to 125,000 francs for the fifth solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy a sizable quantity of cosmetics and cart-loads of fruit and vegetables.

Supplies of merchandise are gotten in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) and in Kimparana. Sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, at the weekly marketplaces of surrounding villages in San and of Kimparana.

The group members each envision realizing a profit of 140,000 francs CFA in the course of the cycle. In addition to making loan payments, the profits will be used for coping with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products and fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Sabaly (La Patience) Group

texts.fr:
Sabaly est un regroupement de  femmes de  Kimparana (région de Ségou) qui se connaissent bien à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 3  enfants.
 Elles mènent différentes activités qui sont entre autres la   restauration, la vente de condiments, et  de fruits.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux années. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125.000 FCFA pour le troisième  prêt solidaire. Tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter  des sacs de riz à San et des condiments alimentaires de toutes sortes pour la restauration. Quant aux fruits  ils sont achetés au fur et à mesure qu’elles sont vendus car ne pouvant être stocké longtemps. Elles vendent leurs marchandises dans des gargotes,  au marché et devant la porte de leur maison
 Ainsi avec ce prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 140 000 FCFA. de bénéfice au cours du cycle.
 En plus du remboursement du prêt elles utiliseront une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. .
texts.en:
Sabaly is a group of women of Kimparana (Ségou region) who know one another well through ties of kinship and community. Averaging 33 years of age, they are married and the mothers of at least three children. The women do different work, including food catering and selling condiments and fruit.

To expand their businesses, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. Loan amounts have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan to 125,000 francs for the third solidarity loan (group loan). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The current loan will be used to buy sacks of rice in San and some condiments of all kinds for preparing and selling food. As for the fruit, it's purchased as it's sold because it cannot be stored for long. Sales are made in eateries, at the marketplace, and outside their front doors.

Thus, with this loan, the group members plan to realize an average profit of 140,000 francs in the course of the cycle. In addition to making loan payments, they will use a portion of the revenues for coping with common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and condiments for catering and to buy fruit

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est Composé  de neuf  femmes (huit mariées et une veuve) vivant majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques. Elles  sont âgées en moyenne de 38 ans avec  4 enfants et vivent toutes dans le village de Sirakoro  (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage,  de parenté, de voisinage et  font essentiellement  le commerce d’articles divers au marché de Médine.
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement  remboursés ses six précédents prêts solidaires, il est à son septième  qui sera  utilisé pour acheter,  40 sacs de henné transformé en poudre, 6 cartons de sparadrap (bandes collantes pour le henné), 1sac d’urée (utilisé pour renforcer la couleur noire du henné), 10 cartons de savon en morceau, 3 douzaines de savon liquide, 3sacs de mil, 2sacs de haricot, 50kg de gueni et de magnonkissèni (noyaux de plantes sauvages exotiques) et 5 bouteilles d’eau de Cologne. Le gueni, le magnonkissèni et les eaux de Cologne sont transformés en encens pour la vente. Elles s’approvisionnent  au grand marché de Ségou et quelques fois à Tissala. Elles vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement  composée de femmes à domicile, en ambulant au village, au marché de Médine et quelques fois au grand marché de Ségou. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 39 500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt, la participation aux évènements sociaux et la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales. 
Elles ont pour ambition l’achat des vaches pour avoir du lait  à boire, à vendre et utiliser leurs bouses  comme  fumure organique pour fertiliser leurs champs
texts.en:
The Danaya is a group composed of nine women (eight married and one widowed) living in monogamous families and averaging 38 years of age and four children each. They all live in the village of Sirakoro (fourth administrative region of Mali). The women know one another through ties of marriage, kinship, or community, and they essentially do commerce in various goods at the Médine marketplace.

Wanting to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing customer base, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. After having correctly repaid their six preceding solidarity loans, they are now on their seventh, which will be used to buy: forty bags of henna processed into powder, six boxes of band-aids (for the henna), one bag of urea (used for enriching the black color of the henna), ten boxes of bar soap, three dozen of liquid soap, three bags of millet, two bags of beans, 50 kg of gueni and magnonkissèni (seeds of wild exotic plants), and five bottles of eau de cologne. The gueni, magnonkissèni, and the perfume are made into incense to be sold.

Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Ségou and sometimes in Tissala. Sales are made to customers essentially composed of women, cash or credit accepted, in their homes, door-to-door in town, at the Médine marketplace, and sometimes at the grand marketplace of Ségou.

The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 39,500 francs CFA that will be use to repay the loan, to participate in social events, and to cover certain family expenses. Their ambition is to buy cows to obtain milk to drink and to sell, as well as to use their dung as organic manure to fertilize the fields.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Kuoh Julius

texts.en:
Julius is married with three children and lives in Belo, Cameroon. Julius has been running a tailoring business for some time now. He purchases many pants and tailors them to his customers' specifications. With this loan, Julius would like to buy 40 pairs of pants, some thread for sewing, and buttons.

This is Julius's second loan from GHAPE since he became a beneficiary in 2007. He did well enough with his first loan that he can now take out a much larger loan. With the last loan he was able to increase his business capital, and now he looks to do the same with this loan. Julius has a variety of customers ranging from school children to his adult neighbors, and believes he does so well because he is a unique suit specialist in his area.

Julius notes that he sews uniforms for Mjangi groups in his community. Theses groups exist to provide financial services to their members. They meet regularly and everyone contributes dues to the group. At each meeting a different person will receive the group's dues, a variation of micro-finance. Julius caters to these groups who often purchase uniforms from him.

With the profits from this loan, Julius will help pay his children's school fees. He also plans to put away money for medical emergencies. He will also use part of his profits to put back into his business, as he did this with his last loan. Julius takes out GHAPE loans because of the favorable loan conditions and he appreciates the business guidance they provide.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buying trousers, thread and buttons

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is married and lives with her husband and sister-in-law, and also has seven children. She lives in Belo, Cameroon where she conducts her business of buying and selling corn. She also sells Koki, a local food made from Koki beans, similar to white beans. With this loan, Roseline will buy two bags of corn, a tin of palm oil, and some wood for cooking. 

This is Roseline's second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. Her business is not new to her as she has been running it for a long time and therefore knows success and sees it in her business’s future. Selling her food in the Belo Market, she has customers that buy from her regularly. 

Roseline has a few items she will attend to with her profits. She mentions that she wants to increase her business capital first. Then, she hopes to buy a larger pot for cooking Koki. As she did with her last loan, she will contribute money to her childrens' school fees. Roseline, not having a lot of money herself, plans to donate during her village development meeting that is held once a year. She enjoys GHAPE loans because of the preferable loan conditions and the business training that GHAPE provides.  
  
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy corn, palm oil, and firewood

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Kotognontala est composé  de quatre femmes (trois mariées et  une veuve) qui  vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygames  dans   le village de Sirakoro (4ème région administrative de la république du Mali) avec en moyenne 43 ans et  4 enfants.
 Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage et mènent les mêmes activités de petit commerce dans le marché de Médine.
Après six prêts solidaires tous correctement remboursés, Kotognontala est à son septième prêt qui servira à acheter, 15 sacs de henné transformé en poudre, 3 sacs de haricot, 2 sacs de mil, 1sac de riz, 1sac de farine de blé, 20 litres d’huile, 1sac de sucre (la farine de blé, l’huile et le sucre sont transformés en gâteaux); des condiments alimentaires :6 sacs de feuilles de baobab réduites en poudre, 5 sacs de gombo sec, 5 sacs de facohoye :feuilles vertes d’une plante sauvage séchées et écrasées utilisées dans les sauces locales).
Elles s’approvisionnent  au grand marché de Ségou et quelques fois  dans le village voisin de  Tissala. Elles vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle    composée de femmes et  d’hommes à domicile, en ambulant au village et au marché de Médine. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 47.000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé  pour  le remboursement du prêt, la participation aux évènements sociaux et pour constituer petit à petit les trousseaux de mariage de leurs filles. 
Elles ont pour ambition de pérenniser leurs activités commerciales afin d’avoir petit à petit des animaux de trait et destinés à l’agriculture.
texts.en:
Kotognontala is a group composed of four women (three married and one widowed) who live for the most part in polygamous families in the village of Sirakoro (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and who average 43 years of age and 4 children each. The women know one another through ties of married, kinship, and community, and they do the same work, small-scale commerce at the Médine marketplace.

After six solidarity loans, all correctly repaid, Kotognontala is on its seventh loan, which will serve to buy: 15 sacks of powdered henna, 3 sacks of beans, 2 sacks of millet, 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of wheat flour, 20 liters of oil, 1 sack of sugar (the flour, oil, and sugar are made into cakes), and some condiments (6 sacks of powdered baobab leaves, 5 sacks of dried okra, and 5 sacks of facohoye, which are the green leaves of a wild plant that are dried, crushed, and used in local sauces).

Supplies of goods are gotten at the grand marketplace of Ségou and sometimes in the neighboring village of Tissala. Sales are made to customers composed of women and men, cash or credit accepted, in homes, door-to-door in town, and at the Médine marketplace.

The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 47,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to assist with social events, and to build up little by little the hope chests for their daughters. The ambition of the women of the group is to perpetuate their businesses in order to gradually acquire draft animals for agriculture.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: add to her inventory

loans.name: Massouko

texts.fr:
Massouko D. est une veuve de 60 ans qui vit avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants chez son défunt mari à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’initia très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente  de pagnes wax, de bracelets, de  tissus brodés,  de draps de lit, de colliers  pour enfants etc. Massouko évolue dans ce créneau depuis maintenant trente ans. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six  ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association JIGUISSEME de Sanoubougou I), elle est à son 7ème prêt individuel et  tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 10 complets de tissus brodés, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 60 draps de qualités différentes et des centaines de colliers  pour enfants. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) ensuite elle les revend chez elle et  de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes, en détail au comptant et quelques à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Massouko D. is a 60-year-old widow who lives with her co-wife and their children in the home of her late husband in Sanoubougou I, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to attend school for societal reasons, she soon got introduced to income-generating work, notably buying and selling Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), bracelets, embroidered fabrics, bed sheets, necklaces for children, etc. Massouko has been improving in her niche market for thirty years now.

Wanting to do better in satisfying her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over six years ago. After four solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area (Association JIGUISSEME de Sanoubougou I), she is now on her seventh individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, she plans to buy 10 outfits of embroidered fabrics, 10 bolts of Wax pagnes, 60 bed sheets of different grades, and a hundred-some necklaces for children. Supplies of goods are gotten in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and then are sold at home or door-to-door to customers composed generally of women, cash accepted and credit at times.

She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Levinus

texts.en:
Levinus is married to Carolyne and they have two children. He lives in Belo, Cameroon, where he has a small retail store selling food and other small items, and he also does some farming. He will use his loan to purchase farming tools, buy a permit for his business, and cover transport costs. For his store, he will also buy palm nuts, groundnuts (peanuts) and kola nuts.

Taking out this loan will allow Levinus to continue his business in Belo. His customers in the community will be able to take advantage of the supply of palm nuts and firewood, which would otherwise be hard to obtain. Levinus believes his business will be successful because his store is in a well-placed location and he tries to keep a good stock of products. He also allows his customers to purchase goods in the quantity they desire.

This is Levinus's second loan from Kiva partner, GHAPE, since he became a beneficiary in 2007. He reinvested the profits from his first loan back into his business by purchasing firewood. He plans on using the same tactic with the profits from this loan by 'increasing his business.' He also wishes to pay for his children’s school fees and make improvements to his house. Levinus chooses GHAPE loans because he finds the repayment conditions preferable, and he appreciates the trust and sense of community GHAPE creates for its members.

More about GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy provisions for his store and farming tools, and to pay permit fees and transport costs

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a widow with eight children. She farms her rented plot with cassava (a starchy vegetable similar to a potato) and groundnuts (peanuts). She will use this loan to purchase these vegetables for planting, buy zinc to cover the roof of her house, and the last part, which is about $20 of the loan, will go towards her farm rent.

This is Pauline's second loan from Kiva partner, GHAPE, since she became a beneficiary in 2007. She has been successful in her farming business in the past and believes she will continue to be so. Pauline thinks she has a good site for her business and she knows that good customer relations keep her business fruitful.

Pauline has faced challenges in her life, including overcoming hunger and poverty. She understands the difficulties facing her customers, too, so when they need her products she is willing to sell them on credit. Pauline plans to put the profits from this loan towards her children’s school fees. She will also help support the older and sick members of her family. Pauline takes out GHAPE loans because she prefers the loan conditions.

More about GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy cassava and groundnuts for planting, zinc for her roof, and pay farm rent

loans.name: Phy's Group

texts.en:
This loan is for a group of four members, all of whom live in Kandal Province. The group leader is Phy I., a 36-year-old single woman. Since 2003 Phy I. has made a living by sewing clothes in the garment industry, for which she receives a salary of $100 per month. She currently takes a taxi to work and hopes to reduce her transport costs by using her loan to buy a used motorbike to ride to work. The other three borrowers are:
– D., a seamstress in the garment industry, requesting a loan for her husband to buy vegetables to sell
– S., a garment worker, requesting a loan to run a fruit store
– P., a garment supervisor, asking for a loan to run a tailoring service from her home.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike

loans.name: Femi

texts.en: Femi is 32 years old and married with a child. He sells motorcycle spare parts. He is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more motorcycle spare parts to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motorcycle spare parts to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married and has one child. He lives in Belo, Cameroon, where he has his small retail store selling various food items. His business is located in the Belo Market, where most of the retail businesses exist in Belo. With this loan, Emmanuel plans to purchase two bags of rice, ten rolls of cigas (cigarettes, 20 packets in each roll), some biscuits and loaves of bread. 

Despite his business being in a competitive market and being so small, Emmanuel believes in his ability to continue his businesses success. He has experience selling his items in this busy market and knows that he has a good customer base. Supplying his community not only provides them with the items they need, but does so at a lower cost, because otherwise they may have to travel farther and pay more in transportation. 

This is Emmanuel's second loan from GHAPE since he became a beneficiary in 2007. His first loan was used for buying items for his store and he has been profitable with this strategy. With the profits from his last loan he was able to buy a new zinc roof for his house. The profits from this loan will go towards paying his child’s school fees as well as supporting other members of his family. Emmanuel takes out GHAPE loans because he gets his loan before he starts to repay it and because of the education they provide on poverty alleviation. 
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase rice, cigas (cigarettes), biscuits and bread

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is single and has two older children. She works in the Belo Market selling goods from her small store. With this loan, Regina plans to purchase one bag of rice, five bags of salt, 10,000cfas (approx. $20) worth of dry fish, ten tins of gari (local vegetable), lots of onions and Maggi (a local, popular sauce used for cooking). 

This is Regina's second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. She thinks she has a good business that is successful. She thinks this because she sells her items to her customers on a daily basis and knows that they need what she offers.  

Having lost her son two years ago and having to pay for her daughter to go to the hospital when she fell ill, Regina has fought some battles recently. She still continues to support her children’s needs through her business. With the profits of this loan, Regina wants to continue to eat better and purchase some new kitchen utensils. She prefers GHAPE loans not only because of the preferable loan conditions but also because of the business skills she was able to acquire with the GHAPE training.  
  
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase provisions for store

loans.name: Devorah

texts.en: Devorah  C., 65, is a widow, blessed with seven children.  She presently resides in Katipa, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental.  Devorah owns a little sari-sari store at her home.  Devorah needed PHP 10,000 to buy goods and inventory.  She gained the confidence needed to manage a business with the help of Paglaum.  Devorah says she stays in good standing by religiously paying her loans on a timely manner.  She hopes to live a good life in her old age.

loans.use: Buy canned goods and other inventory.

loans.name: Sam's Group

texts.en:
These three borrowers have jointed together to get a loan, and Mrs. S. leads the group. S. is a local food seller. She sells to seamstresses who work in garment factories. She makes about $3 per day to feed her family. She is married to VeaSna, 29, who earns a living as a garment worker. The couple is very responsible and their three children are school age. Now S. needs to satisfy more customers by seeking a loan from HKL to increase her business capital.

The other borrowers are: L., a food seller is looking for a loan to expand her business operations. S. is a domestic hairdresser requesting a loan to order hairdressing materials. They all live in Kandal Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: Increase business capital.

loans.name: Kayode

texts.en: Kayode A. is 33 years old and married with two children.  He sells building materials like nails and roofing sheets. He is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more building materials to sell.  He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more building materials to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing used clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Akeem

texts.en: Akeem A. is 33 years old and married with two children.  He sells industrial pipes that are used for transporting water from bore holes and taps to tanks for building and domestic uses.  He is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more industrial pipes to sell.  He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more pipes to sell.

loans.name: Tunde

texts.en: Tunde O. is 27 years old and single.  He sells building materials like nails, saw blades, painting brushes, chisels and screw driver etc.  He is requesting a loan of N100 000 to purchase more building materials to sell.  He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more building materials to sell.

loans.name: Kiko

texts.en:
Kiko J. sells cooking oil, tomatoes and beans and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.

Kiko is a 47 year old widowed. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.
