BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a shop.

loans.name: Fatai

texts.en: Fatai A. is 34 years old and married with three children.  He sells building nails.  He is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more building nails to sell.  He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more building nails to sell.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice J. sells cooking oil, tomatoes and oranges and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Joice is 42 years old and is married to a business man. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a shop.

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona I.  is currently in the business of selling fish and onions and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.  Lona is 39 years old and is widowed.   She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is 35 years old and she is married with 5 children. She is a tailor and she also sells tailoring materials. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 60,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora J. is currently in the business of selling beans and mangoes and is requesting a loan to buy beans, dale, rice, and other food to sell.  Flora is 45 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 5 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy produce and grains to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions like noodles, tomato paste, milk, etc. She started this business in the year 2003. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Amuda

texts.en: Amuda sells cooked foods like moi moi. Moi moi is a local food in Nigeria that is made from beans. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. She is 55 years old and married with 6 children. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 52 years old and married with 2 children. She sells engine oil retail to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more engine oil to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase engine oil

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells crates of eggs and she has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. She hopes to expand this business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase eggs

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Greetings from Angelique M. in Rwamagana, Rwanda!  Angelique has recently completed repayment of her first loan from Vision Finance Company.  She is now requesting a second loan worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be repaid on a monthly basis over eight months.  

Angelique owns a general store in Rwamagana, in the Eastern Province of Rwanda.  She employs two people to help her with her shop.  She intends to use the loan to buy more sacks of sugar and rice to sell in smaller quantities to her customers.  As basic cooking ingredients, those two items are her fastest sellers and she is sometimes unable to carry enough in stock to meet her customers' demands.  

Angelique is 39 years old and married.  She has seven children between the ages of 18 and 5.  She plans to use the profits from her business to buy more food for her family.

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 48 years old and married with 2 children. She is a hair stylist and she also sells hair extensions, hair cream, and bed sheets. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and bed sheets to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and bed sheets

loans.name: Bonafride

texts.en:
Greetings from Bonafride M. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Bonafride, a 49-year-old mother of four children, has owned a shop selling fruits and vegetables for two years, and she is requesting her first loan of 300,000 Rwandan Francs from Vision Finance Company to help her buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.  

Bonafride works everyday from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m., earning approximately 60,000 Rwandan Francs in profit each month ($120).  She plans to use the profits from her business to reinvest in her shop so that it can continue to grow.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Verena

texts.en:
Greetings from Verena M. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Verena is requesting her third loan from Vision Finance Company.  She would like a loan of 300,000 Rwandan Francs so that she can buy more inventory for her general store.  She will pay it back on a monthly basis over a period of 8 months.  

Verena has owned her shop for ten years.  She employs one person to help her to run it, and she works daily from 7:00am to 7:30pm.  She is 32 years old and married with two children and she cares for two additional dependents.  She plans to use her profits to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her shop

loans.name: Saidzhafar

texts.ru: Алимов Саиджафар, проживающий в районе Восе возрост 37 лет, женат имееет троих детей. Имеет среднее обоазование клиент занимается торговлей мясом на местном рыеке Хулбук этим видом деятельности занимается уже более 12 лет. На получившие деньги, клиент хочет закупить скот откормить и  перепродать в виде мясо.От получаемого  дохода клиент содержит семью.
texts.en:
Saidzhafar A. lives in the Vose region. He is 37 years old, married and has three children. He finished secondary school and sells meat in the local market, Xulbuk. He has been in this sort of business for more than 12 years. With the money he will receive, he wants to purchase cattle to fatten to sell for the meat. The client will support his family off the income.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle for resale as meat

loans.name: Scholastique

texts.en:
Greetings from Scholastique M. in Rwamagana, Rwanda!  Scholastique has owned a shop in the Eastern Province of Rwanda for two and a half years.  She is now requesting her first loan so that she can buy more clothes in bulk to resell to her customers.  She will pay back the 500,000 Rwandan Franc loan on a monthly basis over a period of 8 months.  

Scholastique is 34 years old, married, and has six children.  Her children are aged 14, 11, 6, 5, and 3 years, and her youngest is 10 months.  In addition, she cares for two orphans.  She plans to use the profits from her business to reinvest back into her shop so that it can continue to grow.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Greetings from Florence W. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Florence owns a mobile phone shop in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  She has been in business for three years and works daily from 7:00am to 9:30pm.  She is seeking her first microfinance loan so that she can increase her inventory and meet her customers' demands.  The loan will be repaid on a monthly basis over a period of 8 months. 

Florence is 26 years old, single, and cares for two orphans.  She is hoping to use her profit to reinvest in her business so that she can aid in its growth.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Greetings from Clementine K. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Clementine has owned her own salon in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda, for two years.  She has one employee who helps her keep her salon open from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm every day.  She is requesting her first loan of 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be repaid on a monthly basis over a period of 8 months.  

Clementine is 28 years old, married, and has two children.  She also cares for one orphan.  She is hoping to use the profits from her business to reinvest in the salon so that she can increase its rate of growth.

loans.use: To buy more materials for the salon

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Greetings from Angelique N. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Six months ago, Angelique opened a pub in her neighborhood in the capital city of Kigali to supplement her husband's monthly earnings.  She is now seeking her first microfinance loan so that she can increase the number of beverages available to her customers.  She is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be paid back on a monthly basis over an 8 month period.  

Angelique is 29 years old, married, and has two children. She also cares for two dependents.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for her pub

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Since 1998, Eugenia has grown cereals and grapes. She lives with her parents and works on 2 ha of land where she plants corn, sunflowers, and vines. Last year Eugenia produced 3,000 kg of corn, 1,500 kg of sunflowers, and 1,500 kg of wine. She sells sunflower oil to villagers. 

Her first loan in the amount of 5,000 MDL issued by Microinvest helped Eugenia to acquire vine seedlings. She proved to be a good client, paying back the loan in time. Now Eugenia needs another 5,000 MDL for working capital – for seedlings, fuel, and fertilizers.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Carlos Luciano

texts.es:
Carlos inició el negocio por deseos de superarse y de que su familia tuviera un mejor nivel de vida, para lo cual era necesario tener otro ingreso aparte del que recibo por su trabajo dentro de una empresa. 
Comenzó el negocio en Octubre de 1992 como su papá siempre se ha dedicado al transporte, le ofreció que trabajara con él por un tiempo, pero como realmente le gustó el trabajo y le empezó a ir muy bien, decidío seguir trabajando en el transporte público y así tener un ingreso extra para cubrir los gastos de la casa y de la familia. Actualmente trabaja en una empresa entre semana y los sábados y domingos  en el Taxi.

Le ha ido muy bien ya que gracias al Taxi ha podido avanzar en la construcción de su casa para que su familia pueda vivir con mayor comodidad.

El necesita un prestamo por MXN $7,000 que le va a servir para pagar la tenencia y derechos para estar al corriente y no tener problemas de circulación con los Agentes de tránsito.
texts.en:
Carlos started his business in hope of improving his life and achieving a better standard of living for his family. Such improvements required that he find other income separate from what he earned from his job working at a company. He started his business in October of 1992. His father had worked his whole life in transportation, so he offered Carlos a chance to work with him for a little while. When Carlos ended up actually enjoying the work and began to do well with it, he decided to continue working in public transportation. This earned him the extra income he needed to cover his household and family expenses. Today Carlos works at a company during the work week and drives his taxi on the weekends. Thanks to the taxi, things have been going very well. He has been able to advance construction on his house, so that his family can live in greater comfort. He needs a loan of MXN $7,000 to help him to pay road taxes and driving fees needed to remain up to date and stay out of trouble with the transportation authorities.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: pago de tenencia y placas

loans.name: Jorge Martin

texts.es:
Jorge inició el negocio porqué siempre tuve la idea que era una actividad que dejaba buenas ganancias ya que siempre existirán personas que tienen la necesidad de utilizar transporte público como empleados, alumnos, maestros, amas de casa, etc. y de esta forma podría obtener un ingreso para sostener a su familia. 
Comenzó el negocio en Octubre de 1988 empezo como chofer de un microbús de ruta fija y posteriormente compro su propio vehículo para empezar a trabajar por su cuenta, aunque con el inconveniente de que tenía que rentar las placas, pero gracias a Dios ya cuenta con su propia concesión y con un carro de modelo más reciente. Por lo anterior, no se puede quejar ya que le ha ido muy bien y lo que le gusta de mi trabajo es que el puede establecer su horario. 
 

El necesita un prestmo por MXN $7,000 para  pagar la tenencia y derechos para estar al corriente y no tener problemas de circulación con los Agentes de tránsito.
texts.en:
Jorge started his business because he always thought that this would allow him to make good money, now that there are so many people who need to use public transport such as workers, students, teachers, housemaids,etc. and in this way he would be able to support his family. He got into the business in October of 1988, beginning as a driver of a microbus with a fixed route. Later he bought his own vehicle in order to start working for himself, although with the inconvenience of having to rent the taxi permit. But now, Thank God, he has his own permit and a newer model car. As for what went before, he can't complain now that things are going well for him, and what he likes about his work is being able to set his own schedule. He needs a loan of 7,000 Pesos in order to pay the road tax and permit fees, so as to be current and not have traffic problems with the Transit Police.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay road tax and permit fees.

loans.name: Drocella

texts.en:
Greetings from Drocella M. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Twelve years ago, Drocella opened a butcher shop in the capital city of Kigali in Rwanda.  She has since taken out and successfully repaid six loans from Vision Finance Company.  She is now seeking her seventh loan so that she may continue to expand her business.  The loan she is requesting is worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs and she will repay it on a monthly basis over an 8-month period.  

Drocella has one employee at her butchery who helps her keep the shop open from 7:00 am to 7:00 pm every day.  She has grown to the extent that she can now earn nearly 240,000 Rwandan Francs each month (or almost 500 USD).  She is 43 years old, widowed, and has four children.  With the profits from her business, Drocella pays school fees.  She is hoping that if this loan enables her profits to increase she will be able to build her own home.

loans.use: To buy meat for her butchery

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.es:
Maria de Jesus inició el negocio porqué siempre le gustaron las ventas y desde muy joven se dedico al comercio y gracias a ello ha podido junto con su esposo sacar adelante a sus hijos.
Comenzó el negocio En Marzo de 2002 vendiendo taquitos en la parte de enfrente de su casa y luego acondiciono un lugar en las esquina de su casa donde se pude instalar mejor acomodando algunas mesas y sillas para que sus clientes pudieran estar mas cómodos. A partir de julio de 2005 comenzo a elaborar banquetes para todo tipo de fiestas. 

Desde que inicio le ha ido muy bien y en la actualidad cuenta con bastante mobiliario como loza y mantelería, cubre-manteles en 8 tonos diferentes, para los gustos de sus clientes y además acaba de adquirir un equipo de sonido para un servicio más completo a sus clientes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por MXN $12,000 para comprar materia prima y elaborar sus banquetes y algo de mantelería para ir supliendo los manteles que se van deteriorando con el uso.
texts.en:
Maria de Jesus began the business because she always liked selling and from very young she dedicated herself to it. Thanks to the business she has been able to, along with her husband, push her children forward. In March 2002 she began selling taquitos in the front part of her house and soon she arranged a place in the corner of her house where she could install better accommodations, some tables and chairs, so that her customers would be more comfortable. As of July 2005 she began to elaborate banquets for all type of celebrations. Ever since she began the business, it has gone very well for her and currently she relies on enough household goods like plates, table linens, and table cloths in 8 different tones, for her customers’ tastes. In addition, she has just finished acquiring sound equipment for a more complete service. She is requesting a loan to buy raw materials, to elaborate her banquets, and to replace some table linens that have deteriorated with use.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Claude

texts.en:
Greetings from Claude K. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Eight years ago, Claude opened a general store in his neighborhood in the capital city of Rwanda.  He is now seeking his first microfinance loan so that he can buy more stock and better meet his customers' needs.  He is requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be repaid on a monthly basis over an 8 month period.  

Claude has two employees who help him with the shop.  He works from 6:00 am to 10 pm daily, which allows him to earn approximately 200,000 Rwandan Francs each month (or 400 USD).  He is married, and his wife also owns a store nearby.  Claude is 29 years old and has three children.  He intends to use some of his profits to reinvest in his shop so that he can carry a greater variety of goods.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Danny

texts.es:
El señor Danny vive en casa de sus padres en la calle Villcanota de la zona de Munaypata de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como empleado de marketing en una institución, con esta actividad el cubre sus necesidades de alimentación y estudio, el crédito que solicita es para la compra de una computadora para su uso personal.

No es cliente de Impro pero por el carácter social califica para obtener un crédito
texts.en:
Señor Danny lives in his parents' house on Villcanota Street in the Munaypata neighborhood of the city of La Paz. He works in marketing for an institution and this activity pays for his food and school expenses. The loan he is requesting is to buy a computer for his personal use. He is not a client of IMPRO but because of his social standing he qualifies for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Valeriu

texts.en: Valeriu owns 1.5 ha of vines in Sardone and Moldova. He sells the grapes to a local processing enterprise. Last year, on his arable land of 4 ha he cultivated wheat on 2.5 ha, corn on 1.5 ha, and sunflowers on 1 ha. Valeriu has been farming for more than 10 years. As do many other farmers, he also raises pigs and sheep for both market and family consumption. For the future, Valeriu plans to increase the number of sheep he raises.

loans.use: To buy more sheep

loans.name: Alexandru

texts.en: Alexandru has grown potatoes and vegetables for about 12 years. He started this business with his parents and today continues it with his wife. They work 0.77 ha of land and have a greenhouse of 150 m2. They decided to dig a well to irrigate the potatoes and vegetables. Alexandru is helped by his wife in the land cultivation, but sells the produce alone in the town of Dubasari. The business seems to be profitable, as Alexandru has persevered for 10 years already and has his own clients. He plans to produce in greater quantities and possibly add other kinds of vegetables.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Elisaphanie

texts.en:
Greetings from Elisaphanie M. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Elisaphanie has been selling shoes in Rwanda's capital city for ten years.  He is now requesting his first loan to help him expand the business.  The loan is worth 300,000 Rwandan Francs and he will pay it back on a monthly basis over an 8-month period.  

Elisaphanie has one employee and together they sell shoes from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm daily.  He is able to earn approximately 180,000 Rwandan Francs in profit each month (or $350 USD).  Married with 3 children, Elisaphanie is 31 years old.

loans.use: To buy more shoes

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria’s occupation for more than 15 years has consisted of raising pigs, and she has learned this work from her parents ever since she was a child. She owns 20 pigs at this time but soon she will increase their number. Taking into account that the price for fodder is lower at the moment, Maria aims to acquire a lot of fodder. Maria is doing all the necessary activities – producing, examining, selling, etc. The pork is sold at markets in the towns of Balti and Vulcanesti. The price of pork in that region is constant and high. For the future, Maria aims to increase the number of pigs she has from 20 at this time to 50.

loans.use: To buy pigs

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Greetings from Charlotte M. in Kigali, Rwanda!  Charlotte has been a tailor in Kigali for five years and has previously taken out seven microfinance loans.  She is currently requesting a loan worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs, payable on a monthly basis over an 8 month period.  

She has one employee at her tailoring shop who helps her to fill the orders of her customers.  She works from 9:00am to 7:00pm every day.  Charlotte is married with two children and one orphan whom she cares for.  Her husband is a driver of a taxi in town.  She intends to use the profits from her business to continue to reinvest in the shop so that it can grow.

loans.use: To buy more materials to make clothing

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.es:
El señor Jhonny vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijos en la calle Ramos Gavilan de la zona de Achachicala de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene un auto el cual lo trabaja como transporte publico (Taxi) con este trabajo el puede aportar para la manutención de su familia, ya que su esposa trabaja como profesora y su sueldo no les alcanza. El crédito que solicita es para la reparación y mantenimiento de su movilidad y poder mantener esta fuente de ingresos

Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. Es cliente nuestro desde el año 2007.
texts.en:
Mr. Jhonny lives in his own house with his wife and children on Ramos Gavilan Street in the Achachicala zone of La Paz. He has an automobile which he uses as public transport (a taxi). With this work, he can support and maintain his family since his wife works as a teacher and her salary is not enough for them. The loan he is requesting is for the repair and maintenance of his mobility and to be able to maintain this source of income. Since 2007 he has been a customer of ours and his history qualifies him as a good customer. As a result, he can agree to a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair and maintenance of his taxi.

loans.name: Kokou Essozinam

texts.en: K. is 27 years old and single.  He began selling gas, car oil, and fuel for kitchen fuel tanks in 2008.  He sells his merchandise next to gas stations and petrol warehouses.  Presently, his stock is insufficient to meet the demands of his clients, and he is, therefore, seeking credit to buy more gas, oil, and kitchen fuel.

loans.use: To buy gas, car oil, and fuel for household fuel tanks

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa A. is 50 years old. She is married and has six children: two of them are currently in school and the others are out of school and living independently. She lives with her husband and two children in a family house in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Adwoa is a baker. She bakes meat pies and sells them to retailers. She also distributes her products to snack-bar operators. Adwoa also bakes and fries other pastries. She procures the raw materials such as flour, margarine, sugar, cooking oil, and so forth, from wholesalers in the nearby towns. Adwoa has been in this business for 30 years now and has won a number of customers over the years. She wants a loan to procure the ingredients in bulk so can supply her products to more customers and make more profit. The increased profits will help her pay for her children’s school bills.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Ayellefu

texts.en: Ayellefu A. is 43 years old. She is married and has two two children. One of them has completed the senior high school while the other is yet to complete. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. Ayellefu sells cereals such as maize and beans so she can earn some income to help support her family. She procures the food items from the farmers in the nearby communities and distributes them to the retailers in her community. She also sells her products to food vendors. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her stock. Ayellefu intends to trek to other markets to do business. She desires to improve upon her standard of living and give her children the best of education.

loans.use: To procure bags of maize and beans

loans.name: Wahibah

texts.en:
Wahibah is a 50 year old woman who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with her husband and their four children. Wahibah has owned a sewing factory for eighteen years. She requested a loan of US $2000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for her work. This is the first time that Wahibah has requested a loan.

Wahibah is special in her work because she does it well. Her clients are traders. When she first started her business, she didn’t have start up capital. She decided on doing her business because of her experience and wanting to improve her financial situation. In the future, she plans on expanding her factory.

loans.use: To purchase tools for sewing

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
In 2002, Angela T. began growing cereals on four hectares of land. She grows corn, wheat, barley, and sunflower. She has a tractor to help her cultivate the soil. In addition to growing cereals, Angela also raises pigs and cattle. In 2007, she took a loan from Microinvest for working capital. She repaid that loan entirely. 

Angela is now asking for a loan so she can buy seedlings, fuel, and fertilizer. She plans to purchase watermelon seedlings because a part of her land is of a lower quality, but is very good for watermelons.

loans.use: To buy  buy seedlings, fuel, and fertilizer

loans.name: Naser

texts.en:
Naser is a 54-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon, with his wife and their seven children. Naser has been selling home products for four years. Naser requested a loan of US $1500 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Naser has requested a loan.

Naser is speciA. in his work because he sells a big variety of items. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Naser decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his income. In the future, he plans on starting a new business which will sell CDs.

loans.use: To purchase home products for resale

loans.name: Ryad

texts.en:
Ryad is a 28 year old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Ryad has owned a coffee shop for four years. He also serves “narguileh” (also known as “shisha” in Egypt). Narguileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Narguileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East, and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, Europe, and other countries. He requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and coffee machine. This is the first time that Ryad has requested a loan. 
Ryad is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he had difficulty finding the proper place to open his shop. Ryad decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his income. In the future, he plans on starting a new business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and coffee machine

loans.name: Jinane

texts.en:
Jinane is a 35-year-old woman who lives in Tripoli in northern Lebanon with her husband and their child. Jinane owns a clothing shop and sells children’s clothes. She requested a loan of 1,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is her second cycle and she has always paid on time.

Her previous loan helped her improve her shop. Jinane is unique in her work because she sells a large variety of clothes. Her clients are her friends, neighbors, and others. When she first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capital. She decided on starting her business because she wanted to improve her financial situation. In the future, she plans on expanding her shop.

loans.use: Jinane will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Wisam

texts.en: Wisam is a 30-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Wisam has been working as an electrician for eleven years.  He has requested a loan of 1000 USD from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his business. This is the first time that Wisam has requested a loan.  Wisam's clients can be anybody from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties.  Wisam decided to be an electrician because of his experience. In the future, he plans to expand his business by opening an electricA. shop.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his electrician business.

loans.name: Anoumou

texts.en: Anoumou M. is a teacher who has three children.  Because his teacher's salary was not sufficient to support him and his children, he began selling the much-loved local beverage, Sodadi, in 2006.  He buys Sodadi in bulk in Tsévié in the country’s interior and transports it to be sold in Lomé, the capital of Togo. M.’s enterprise has been successful thus far because he carefully analyzed his business before beginning. He obtained a loan from Wages in 2006 to begin his business, and he is now seeking a second loan to buy 20 large containers of Sodadi and to transport them to Lomé.

loans.use: Purchase a local beverage

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D. is forty years old. She is a married mother of five children. One of the five children has just completed senior high school. The others are in junior high and primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
Mary is a food vendor. She sells a local dish called ‘banku’ in her community. She prepares the food in her home and sells on the street in the evenings. Banku is prepared from corn dough and served hot with soup. Mary says she buys the raw materials, such as maize, fish, and other vegetables, from the local market. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy raw materials in bulk. She hopes to improve her standard of living and to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es: Elsa tiene 24 años, es madre soltera, pero gracias al apoyo que tiene de sus padres, ha salido adelante y tiene la posibilidad de brindar lo necesario a su pequeña hija de 2 años. A pesar de las dificultades que tuvo en su juventud, Elsa nunca perdió el interés por los estudios y gracias a su empeño académico logró concluir sus estudios de cocina y repostería, obteniendo así, el titulo de chef profesional. Este logro la ayudo a iniciar su propio negocio, junto a su madre, quien cultivo en su hija el arte culinario, y juntas ahora, llevan el negocio de preparación de bocaditos. Por el momento reparten a domicilio, pues no cuentan con un local propio para atención al cliente, pero a pesar de las dificultades y limitaciones han logrado tener una gran acogida con las personas, debido sus deliciosos bocaditos, ya que son preparados con productos de buena calidad. En poco tiempo han logrado gran demanda y se encuentran en la necesidad  de alquilar un local con la finalidad de implementar una fuente de soda o una pastelería, que con el tiempo están seguras será muy reconocida. Elsa está iniciando su primer crédito con MFP y espera que las relaciones con sus compañeras y con la institución sean armoniosas y de gran aprendizaje. Los 800 soles que solicita serán invertidos en la compra de utensilios necesarios para la producción de dulces, además de incrementar la cantidad que requiere para el alquiler de su local.
texts.en:
Elsa is 24 years old and a single mother, but thanks to her parents' support she is getting ahead and has the possibility of providing for her little two-year-old daughter. In spite of the her youthful difficulties, she never lost interest in her studies and through her academic determination she succeeded in completing her training in cooking and pastrymaking, and obtaining the title of professional chef. This achievement helped her to start her own business, together with her mother, who groomed her daughter in the culinary arts. Together now they have opened a business preparing bocaditos (hors dourves and savory snacks). For the time being they are working out of their home because they don't have a location appropriate for their customers. But in spite of the difficulties and limitations they are having success and getting a good reception from the public thanks to their delicious bocaditos which are prepared using the best ingredients. In just a short time they have generated a huge demand and have found it necessary to rent some space with the aim of setting up a soda fountain or a pastry shop, which in time they are certain will become very well known. Elsa is beginning her first loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA and hopes that her relationships with the other members and with the institution will be harmonious and a great learning experience. The 800 Sols which she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of utensils necessary for the production of sweet things, as well as to help pay the rent for their location.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking utensils and pay rent for the business.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama N. is forty-five years old. She is a married mother of three children. One of her children has completed junior high school and is in an apprenticeship. The others are in junior high and primary school. Ama lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
She is a trader. She prepares and sells palm oil. Palm oil is prepared from palm nuts. The cooked palm is pounded, mixed with hot water, strained and boiled for several hours. The reddish substance which is the oil is skimmed off and boiled again to expel water content. Ama buys the palm nuts from the farmers in her community. She distributes the oil to retailers. Ama also sells textiles and utensils. She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy raw materials in bulk. She hopes to improve her standard of living and to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es: La señora Marcela, es una mujer muy trabajadora y comprometida con el desarrollo de su trabajo, familia y de su persona. A pesar de estar separada de su pareja siempre les brindó lo necesario a sus hijos, y gracias a la ayuda de sus padres y familia tienen un calor de hogar, pues todos viven juntos en la casa de sus padres. Sus necesidades como madre y padre la impulsaron a buscar trabajo para cumplir con sus responsabilidades, hallando la oportunidad en una empresa telefónica, donde se desempeñó como promotora de ventas desde hace quince años. Luego inició un negocio más independiente, pero dentro de la misma empresa, que consiste en la venta de teléfonos prepago, útiles para las personas con bajos recursos y con escasa posibilidad de poseer una línea telefónica en casa. De esta manera ayuda a las personas de bajos recursos a tener un medio de comunicación, siendo  esta su mayor satisfacción, no sólo por las ganancias o por la demanda, sino porque contribuye con el desarrollo de su distrito y de su ciudad. Sin embrago, Marcela espera en el futuro instalar un negocio de venta de teléfonos y tarjetas telefónicas en su casa para brindar un servicio a tiempo completo, sin dejar de salir los fines de semana para seguir ayudando en lo posible a las personas que están en zonas más pobres. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, está comprometida a ser responsable y puntual, y junto al equipo de compañeras, quienes son muy dinámicas y trabajadoras, hacer crecer su banco comunal. El dinero que viene solicitando lo estará invirtiendo en la compra de teléfonos que requiere para las ventas de estos meses, ya que en algunos casos la venta es al crédito y hay que cubrir los pagos durante algunos meses.
texts.en:
Ms. Marcela, is a very hardworking woman taking on the improvement of her business, her family and herself. In spite of being separated from her partner she always provided what was necessary for her children, and thanks to the help of her parents and family members they have a warm home in which they all live together in her parents’ home. The demands of being a parent pushed her to look for work in order to manage her responsibilities. Finding an opportunity in a telephone company, she worked as promoter of sales over the last fifteen years. Then she started a more independent business, within the same company, that consists of selling prepaid telephone calls, useful to people with limited resources and scarce possibility of having a telephone in their home. In this way she helps people with limited resources have a means of communication. Doing this gives her great satisfaction, not only for the financial gain or the demand, but because she contributes to the development of her district and her city. Nevertheless, Marcela hopes in the future to set up a business selling phones and phone cards in her home to provide a full-time service while leaving the weekend to continue helping, as much as possible, people in poorer areas. This is her first loan with MFP. She is committed to being responsible and punctual, and work alongside teammates who are very dynamic and hardworking, to enable their community bank to grow. The money she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of telephones that she needs to sell in upcoming months, because in some cases the sale is by credit, and she has to cover payments for several months.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in merchandise

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed A. is forty-seven years old. He is married with four children. Three of them have completed senior high school and have been working for a while. The youngest is still in school. He lives with his children and wife in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 
Mohammed is a trader. He trades in foodstuffs such as yams, plantain, cassava, etc., and in fruits such as oranges.  He buys the goods from the farmers in the nearby small communities at reasonable prices. He treks to other towns to supply his customers. He says food vendors and other retailers are the ones who normally purchase from him. Mohammed has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so that he will be able to distribute to more customers.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and fruits

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha tiene 39 años, vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos en la casa que adquirieron años atrás. Siempre demostró ser muy trabajadora dentro de la comisaría donde presta servicios hace 5 años como cocinera, y gracias a este empleo logró adquirir algunas cosas útiles para su hogar, pero con el tiempo fue ahorrando y adquirió un motocarro hace 4 meses, el cual viene administrando con mucho cuidado, pues tiene que estar pendiente del mantenimiento mensual y tener mucho cuidado con las personas a quienes alquila el vehículo, tratando en lo posible que  dicho instrumento de trabajo, no se deteriore ni se devalúele rápidamente.  La meta de Martha es tener una mecánica donde pueda vender diversas variedades de repuestos, ya que son muy solicitados y costosos, lo cual hace rentable el negocio, y tiene proyectado asociarse con un sobrino que estudió mecánica y ambos abrir el pequeño taller de repuestos. Este es préstamo número veintinueve, y espera seguir trabajando con MFP, sobre todo con las compañeras de su grupo, quienes son muy unidas y en lo posible tratan de mejorar su capacidad de pago. Martha invertirá 2800 en la compra de repuestos para su vehículo, con el fin de estar en continuo mantenimiento de su motocarro.
texts.en:
Martha is 39 years old. She lives together with her husband and two children in the house they acquired three years ago. She’s always proved to be very hardworking inside the police station where she worked for 5 years as a chef. Thanks to this employment she managed to buy some useful things for her home, but with time she was saving money, and she purchased a 3-wheel delivery van (motor car) 4 months ago, which she has been managing with care. She is outstanding with the monthly maintenance and very careful with the people she rents the vehicle to, trying as much as possible to keep this particular working vehicle from deteriorating or declining in value very quickly. Martha’s goal is to have a mechanic’s shop where she can sell diverse varieties of spare parts, because they are very sought-after and expensive, which makes the business profitable. She has plans to partner with a nephew who studied mechanics and together open a small workshop of spare parts. This is loan number 29, and she hopes to continue working with MFP, especially with her group companions who are very committed to the possibility of improving their ability to pay back. Martha will invest 2800 to buy spare parts for her vehicle, with the objective of continually maintaining her motor car.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for her motor car

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha F. is thirty-five years old. She is single and lives alone in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
Agatha is a trader. She trades in secondhand textiles such as women’s clothes and bed sheets. She hawks to sell her goods and treks to other markets to sell. She purchases bales of textiles from wholesalers in the nearby towns. Apart from the textile selling, Agatha also runs a restaurant in her community.
She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure bales of textiles in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes

loans.name: Rosana

texts.es: Rosana desde muy joven deseó tener una casa muy grande y bonita donde vivir, ahora, a sus 40 años ha logrado adquirir con mucho esfuerzo la casa que acaba de terminar de construir. A pesar de las circunstancias trabajó muy duro para terminar su casa, la cual es muy bonita y grande, pues tiene tres pisos y están adecuadamente ambientadas. Pero como no es muy agradable vivir sola dentro de una casa tan grande empezó a alquilar habitaciones a personas solteras y así tener un ingreso que le ayude a satisfacer sus necesidades. Hace 6 años que viene alquilando cuartos, tiene un terreno a lado de su casa y también desea construir para ampliar sus servicios de alquiler. Pero por el momento desea ambientar las habitaciones para una mejor atención a sus huéspedes, quienes le brindan calor de hogar a cada lugar de su casa, lo que la motiva a seguir manteniendo el sueño de casarse algún día y forman un hogar con muchos hijos que espera tener. Rosana está iniciando su primer crédito individual con MFP, pues los anteriores fueron grupales, lo cual la ayudó a relacionarse con las personas y tener mayor información sobre el ámbito financiero. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en los materiales que requiere para el acabado y decorado de sus habitaciones.
texts.en:
Since Rosana was very young, she wanted to have a very large and beautiful house to live in. Now at 40 years old, and with great effort, she’s been able to finish building her house. In spite of the circumstances, she worked very hard to finish this house, which is beautiful and large; it has three floors and is adequately furnished. But since it’s not very pleasant living alone in a very large house, she began renting out rooms to single women, in this way she has an income which helps her meet her expenses. She’s been renting rooms for six years now. She has a field to the side of her house that she wants to build on and broaden her renting services. But, for the moment she wants to furnish the rooms to better accommodate the guests, who provide warmth to every part of the house. This motivates her to pursue her dream of getting married one day and creating a home with children she hopes to have. Rosana is opening her first individual loan with MFP, the pervious were group loans which helped her to get acquainted with people in the financial world. She plans to invest the money in building materials required to finish and decorate the bedrooms.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building materials for finishing and decorating her rental rooms

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas D. is forty-five years old. She is married and has one child who is currently in an apprenticeship. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
Dorcas is a trader. She trades in secondhand textiles, such as clothes for both men and women, and bed sheets. She says she hawks to sell her goods and treks to other markets to sell. She also sells sometimes at the market square in her community. Dorcas buys bales of textiles from wholesalers in the nearby towns.
She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure bales of textiles in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Georgina A. is fifty years old. She is married and the mother of six children. Four of them have completed junior high school and are into apprenticeships, while the others are still in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. Georgina works to make some income to help support the family. She trades in cereals such as maize. She purchases the maize from the farmers in the nearby communities and distributes to the retailers in her community. She also supplies to food vendors. Georgina has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy maize in bulk to increase her stock. She intends to trek to other markets to do business. She wants to improve her standard of living and to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Amenyo

texts.en:
Amenyo Afaokpah is thirty-six years old. He is married with two children. Both children are still in junior high school. He lives with his children and wife in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 
Amenyo is a trader. He trades in agrochemicals. He purchases the chemicals from the agricultural offices in the district capital. He stocks chemicals like insecticides, pesticides, herbicides, and all types of fertilizers.  He owns a shop in which he sells his products. According to him, farmers in the nearby small communities come to buy the chemicals to apply on their farms. He says he also treks to other towns to supply customers there. Amenyo has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure agrochemicals in bulk so that he can distribute to more customers.

loans.use: To buy agrochemicals

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel A. is forty-two years old and married with six children. One of them has just completed senior high school. Two are still in senior high while the others are in junior high and primary schools. He lives with his children and wife in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 
Samuel is a trader. He trades in hardware such as electrical gadgets like extension cords and adapters. He buys the gadgets from the wholesale shops all the way from Accra. He also stocks electrical appliances like refrigerators and fans. He owns a shop in which he sells his products. Samuel says he has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy more hardware to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy electrical hardware

loans.name: Brenda Dalila

texts.es:
La señora  Brenda Dalila  E.  Pérez, pertenece al Banco Comunal “PEQUEÑAS EMPRESARIAS II”, vive en el Jr, circunvalación 1215  Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es soltera y estudiante al mismo tiempo.

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, pudo iniciar su negocio propio, empezó   vendiendo refrigerios, que ofrecía los transeúntes que pasaban por su casa, haciéndose conocida por su buena sazón e higiene en la preparación de sus productos. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal.


En la actualidad se dedica a la Venta de  comidas, ofrece  desayuno, almuerzo  y  cena en un ambiente especialmente acondicionado  en su propia casa , donde sus principales clientes son los policías del penal ,estudiantes del colegio que están  ubicados cerca de su casa  y los moradores de su barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá, comprando platos, ollas, vasos, sillas, sacos de arroz, sacos de azúcar, para dar un mejor servicio y atención a sus clientes. 

Ella es la que  toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio pero cuenta mucho con el apoyo de su mamà. En lo personal, desea  tener su propio restaurante  y se siente más segura con el pago de sus cuotas. 

BRENDA, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria  y mujer.
texts.en:
Brenda Dalila E. Pérez belongs to the “Pequeñas Empresarias II” comunal bank. She lives on street 1215 in the Tarapoto District, San Martín Department. She is single and a student at the same time. With her first loan of S/. 300.00, she was able to begin her own business. She began by selling snacks to pedestrians passing by her house. She became known for her delicious food and good kitchen hygiene in preparing her products. She has been working with the communal bank for 2 years. She now sells meals—breakfast, lunch, and dinner, from a space in her own house that has been set up for this purpose. Her principal customers are the police from the jail, students from the nearby high school, and residents of her neighborhood. With this loan of S/. 800.00, which she will repay over a period of 6 months, she will invest in plates, cooking pots, glasses, chairs, bags of rice, and bags of sugar, so that she can provide better service to her customers. She is the one who makes the decisions regarding the earnings from her business, but she receives much support from her mother. Personally, she wants to have her own restaurant and she feels more secure with her loan payments. Brenda expresses her appreciation to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businessperson and woman.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plates, cooking pots, glasses, and chairs. To buy ingredients: rice and sugar, among others.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia N. is forty-four years old and married with three children. Two of them are currently in senior high school while the others are in junior high school. She lives with her children and husband in their home in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
Felicia is a seamstress by profession. She owns a workshop in the market square. She sews ladies’ dresses for sale and also sews for clients who come with their own materials and place an order. She purchases all kinds of fabrics from fashion shops in the big cities. She has apprentices who are in training, a number of whom have graduated and are now running their own businesses. Felicia has been in this business for twenty years and has won many customers over the years. She wants a loan to buy sewing accessories and fabrics in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fabric and sewing accessories

loans.name: Saida

texts.es:
La señora Saida, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Victorias”, vive en Jr. Pilar Nores S/Nº, Distrito D. Juanjui, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 63 años y es madre D. 04 hijos, 01 que aun depenD. D. ella.

Se inicio con S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia y con el apoyo D. sus hijos comenzó en su casa vendiendo abarrotes en pequeñas cantidades.

En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio, ubicado en su misma casa, donD. sus principales clientes son sus vecinos y amigos.

Con este préstamo D. S/2,000.00 que pagara en un  plazo D. 06  meses, lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, papel higiénico en paquete, leche y conservas D. pescado en cajas, insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela, también comprara un andamio D. madera , para exhibir  sus productos.

Es ella quien  toma las decisiones en las ganancias D. su negocio. En lo personal, nos cuenta que es más Independiente, segura y responsable con el pago D. sus cuotas. 
 
Zaida, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Saida belongs to the Communal Bank, “Las Victorias” and lives in Jr. Pilar Nores South, Juanjui District, Saint Martin Department. She is 63 years old, married and the mother of 4 children, 1 of which still depends on her. She began on her own initiative with a small amount of money, and with the support of her children, began selling groceries in small quantities in her home. Presently she continues with the same business, located in the same house, where her main customers are her neighbors and friends. With this loan, which she will pay over a period of 6 months, she will invest in buying more products to stock her business, products such as rice, sugar sacks, toilet paper packs, milk, canned fish in boxes, personal hygiene supplies, household cleaning products, and various products to keep her customers happy. She will also buy a wooden platform to showcase her products. She personally makes decisions with the earnings of her business and she tells us that she is more independent, safe and responsible with the payment of her dues. Saida expresses her gratituD. to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as an entrepreneur and woman.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth T. is fifty-six years old. She is married and has two sons. Both of them have completed senior high school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
She works hard to make some income to help her husband provide for the family. Elizabeth is a trader. She trades in all kinds of minerals and drinks – malt, coke, fanta, etc. She buys the minerals from the wholesale dealers in the regional capital, Cape Coast, and sells in the community market. She owns a shop in which she sells her products. Elizabeth also sells plastic products. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy her products in bulk.

loans.use: To buy provisions and drinks

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is sixty years old. She is a married mother of two children. She says both of her children have grown up and are living independently. She lives with some grandchildren and husband in a family house in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Mary is a trader in earthen wares. She procures the wares from ceramic artists in a nearby town. Mary treks to other towns to sell her wares on their market days.

She says she also sells at market square in her community. Mary also trades in other products such as pestles and mortars. She supplies her products mostly to local restaurant operators who mostly pound. Mary has been in this business for ten years now and wants a loan to procure the wares in bulk.

loans.use: To buy earthenware for resale

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos tiene la responsabilidad de mantener su hogar, y gracias al apoyo de su pareja han logrado satisfacer las necesidades de sus dos hijos, quienes tienen lo necesario dentro de su casa donde habitan todos como familia. Todas las madrugadas Carlos sale a comprar pescado en las playas que están cercanas a su hogar para luego venderlo en el mercado mayorista, pues la venta de pescado es una de las actividades más rentables en su localidad, debido a que los comerciantes, ya sean mayoristas o  minoristas visitan ese mercado por la calidad y cantidad de productos. Esto favorece el negocio de Carlos, pero lo difícil es despertar a las tres de la mañana y salir a comprar el pescado para  luego trasladarlo al mercado, donde solo puede vender hasta las ocho de la mañana, ya que  los comerciantes sólo salen desde muy temprano, y si por algún motivos demora en llegar, tiene pocas posibilidades de acabar de vender su producto. Es por ello que en cuanto más pronto salga de casa, tiene mayor ventaja de terminar temprano. Con el tiempo, Carlos desea tener una asociación de comerciantes pesqueros para ver la posibilidad de exportar los productos o distribuir a diversas ciudades. Carlos es fundador del grupo que desde hace tres años se formó en MFP, y este es su quinto préstamo. Como presidente de su banco comunal tiene una grata experiencia de trabajar junto a sus compañeras, quienes son muy trabajadoras y comprometidas, a pesar de que por algunas circunstancias se llegaron a desanimar en algún momento, siguen trabajando juntos. Adquirir mayor cantidad de producto ayudará a mejorar sus ingresos, y es lo que hará con los 1500 soles que ahora solicita.
texts.en:
Carlos is responsible for the maintenance of his home. He has been able to meet his two children’s needs thanks to the help of their mother. The children have everything they need in their house where they all live as a family. Every morning at daybreak Carlos leave for the beaches that are closest to his home to buy fish. He later sells them in the wholesale market. Selling fish is one of the most profitable activities in his area because the merchants, big and small, visit this market for its quality and quantity of products. This works to his favor. But, it is difficult to get up at three in the morning, and leave to buy fish to later take to the market, where you can only sell until eight in the morning. The merchants leave very early; if for any reason you are late getting there you have little chance of selling all of your fish. Therefore, the earlier he leaves home, the better chance he has of finishing early. In time, Carlos would like to have a Fishermen’s Merchant Association to see about the possibility of exporting or distributing products to different cities. Carlos is the founder of the group that formed three years ago in MFP. This is his fifth loan. As president of his community bank he has the gratifying experience of working together with his companions. They are very hard working and committed. In spite of the fact that under some circumstances they are momentarily discouraged, they keep working together. Acquiring more product will help him increase his income, and that is what he will do with the 1500 PEN that he is now asking for.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Yolith

texts.es:
La señora Yolith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Corazón de Jesús”, vive en el Jr. Elgiba Ramírez S/Nº - Caserío de San Isidro, Distrito de San José de Sisa, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 40 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 02 que todavía dependen de ella.

Se inicio con S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia  y con el apoyo de su esposo emprendió su  propio negocio de venta de abarrotes.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, ubicada en su misma casa, donde sus principales clientes son sus vecinos y amigos.
Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00 que cancelara a un  plazo de 04  meses, lo invertio comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes y productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Es ella quien  toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. 
 
Yolith, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Yolith belongs to the "Heart of Jesus" community bank. She lives at Elgiba Ramírez S/Nº- Caserío de San Isidro in the San José de Sisa district of San Martín province. Yolith is 40 years old and married. She has three children, two of whom still depend on her economically. With help from her husband, Yolith invested 300 Soles in her own business. She owns a grocery store, which is located in her home. Her principal clients are her friends and neighbors. With a loan of 800 soles Yolith will invest in more products to supply her store. She'll buy sacs of rice and sugar, toiletries, cleaning products, packets of soft drinks, and various products to keep her clients happy. She'll repay the loan in four months. Yolith makes the decisions on how to spend the income from her business. Personally, she feels more independent, safe, and responsible with her loan repayments. Yolith would like to thank Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, cleaning products, and soft drinks

loans.name: Giovana

texts.es:
Giovana es socia del Banco Comunal Kusirikuy que significa Alégrate en quechua.
Giovana es casada, tiene 28 años y 2 hijos, Giovana vende ropa de manera ambulatoria en una calle cercana al mercado central de la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Giovana los días domingo y lunes vende en las ferias.
Giovana necesita un préstamo de 750 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de buzos y polos.
Los sueños de Giovana son seguir ahorrando para tener una tienda y construir su casa.
texts.en:
Giovana is a partner in the Kusirikuy Community Bank. The name means "be happy" in quechua. Giovana is 28 years old and married, with two children. She sells clothes on a street near the main market of Ayachucho city. Giovana also sells in the Sunday and Monday markets. She needs a loan of 750 soles, which she'll invest in sweaters and polo shirts. Giovana dreams of continuing to save so that she can have a store and build a house.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sweaters and polo shirts.

loans.name: Yolith

texts.es:
La señora Yolith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Corazón D. Jesús”, vive en el Jr. Elgiba Ramírez S/Nº - Caserío D. San Isidro, Distrito D. San José D. Sisa, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 62 años y es madre D. 07 hijos, todos independientes.

Se inicio con S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia, se pusieron D. acuerdo con su esposo y así emprendió su  propio negocio D. venta D. abarrotes. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el banco.

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio D. Venta D. Abarrotes, negocio ubicado en su misma casa, donD. sus principales clientes son sus vecinos y amigos.
Con el préstamo D. S/1,000.00 que pagara a un  plazo D. 04  meses, lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, leche y conservas D. pescado en cajas, insumos para el aseo personal, gaseosas en paquetes y productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Ambos, su esposo y ella toman las decisiones en las ganancias D. su negocio. En lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y responsable con el pago D. sus cuotas. 
 
Yolith, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Yolith belongs to the "Heart of Jesus" community bank. She's been working with this community bank for two years. She lives at Elgiba Ramírez S/Nº - Caserío D. San Isidro in the San José D. Sisa district of the San Martín province. Yolith is 62 years old and married. She has seven children, all of whom are financially independent. She started with 300 Soles of her own money, and after reaching an agreement with her husband she opened a grocery store. Yolith's grocery store is located in her home, and her main clients are friends and neighbors. With a loan of 1,000 Soles, Yolith will invest in more products to supply the store. She will buy sacks of rice and sugar, boxes of milk and canned fish, toiletries, packets of soft drinks, and various products to keep her clients happy. She'll repay the loan in four months. Both Yolith and her spouse make decisions regarding income from the business. Personally, Yolith feels more independent, safe, and responsible with her loan repayments. Yolith would like to thank Manuela Ramos for helping her grow as an entrepreneur and a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sugar, milk, preserved goods, soft drinks, and toiletries.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia es socia del Banco Comunal Kusirikuy que significa Alégrate en quechua.
Julia es casada, tiene 48 años y 5 hijos, Julia se dedica a la venta de golosinas, bebidas, frutas, actividad que realiza de manera ambulatoria en la puerta de un colegio para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de sus hijos.
Julia necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas, gaseosas y frutas.
Los sueños de Julia son brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the community bank Kusirikuy meaning "Rejoice" in Quechua.

Julia is married. She is 48 years old and has five children. Julia sells sweets, drinks, and fruits. This activity is mobile and is located at the door of a school for which she counts on her children for help. Julia needs $350 (1050 PEN) which will be invested in the purchase of crackers, soda, and fruit.

Julia's dreams are to provide a good education for her children and to improve her business.


Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy crackers, soda, and fruit

loans.name: Rosa Graciela

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Graciela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “San Marcelo II”, vive en el Jr. Tupac Amaru  Nº 139, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 54 años y es madre de 04 hijos, todos independientes. 

Se inicio con un préstamo de S/. 100.00, por iniciativa propia emprendió la construcción de ambientes para alquiler de dormitorios.
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, y también se dedica a la venta de marcianos de frutas y bebidas como chichas, gaseosas en todos los sabores y diferentes tamaños.

Con el préstamo de S/. 600.00 que cancelara a un plazo de 04 meses, lo invertirá comprando maíz y azúcar en kilos, para la preparación de sus chichas, también comprará gaseosas en paquetes y frutas como pifayos, cocos, uvas, para la elaboración de sus marcianos.

Ella, toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, en lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y capaz.

Rosa Graciela; manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Rosa Graciela belongs to the San Marcelo II community bank. She lives at 139 Tupac Amaru Avenue, Tarapoto District, San Martín Department. She is married, 54 years old and the mother of four grown children. Beginning with a loan of 100 Peruvian nuevos soles, at her own initiative she began construction of dormitory rooms to rent out. She has continued the practice to the present and has branched out into the sale of marcianos (fruit ice cream treats), and beverages like chichas (a maize-based, non-alcoholic fermented drink), as well as soft drinks in all flavors and sizes. With this loan of 600 Peruvian nuevos soles to be repaid in four months, Rosa Graciela will make an investment in purchasing corn and sugar in bulk to make chichas. She will also buy soft drinks by the case and fruit such as peach-palm fruit, coconut and grapes to prepare marcianos. Making business decisions has allowed her to feel more independent, secure and capable personally. Rosa Graciela expresses her thanks to Manuela Ramos for permitting her to grow as a female entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, sugar, soft drinks and fruit

loans.name: Norma Del Pilar

texts.es:
Norma es socia del Banco Comunal Kusirikuy que significa Alégrate en quechua.
Norma es casada, tiene 37 años y 4 hijos, Norma vende frutas variadas, de manera ambulatoria, caminando por diferentes calles para lo cual tiene una carretilla, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos.
Norma necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de manzanas, sandia.
Los sueños de Norma son ahorrar, tener una casa bonita para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Norma is a member of the community bank Kusirikuy, which means “Be Happy” in Quechua. Norma is 37, married and has 4 children. Norma sells various fruit on the street. She walks down different streets, which is why she has a cart. Her children help her sell fruit. Norma needs a loan of 1,050 PEN to buy apples and watermelon. Norma’s dream is to save money to have a nice house for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy apples, watermelon.

loans.name: Ninfa Juana

texts.es:
La señora Ninfa Juana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción”, vive en el Jr. 20 de mayo – Carretera Fernando B. Terry, Distrito de San José de Sisa, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 43 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 02 que todavía dependen de ella.

Se inicio con un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, por iniciativa propia emprendió su  propio negocio de venta de abarrotes.

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio de venta de abarrotes, ubicada en su misma casa, donde sus principales clientes son moradores de la comunidad, vecinos y amigos.
Con el préstamo de S/2,000.00 que cancelara a un  plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, paquetes de leches, aceites e insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes,  y productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Es ella quien  toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. 
 
Ninfa Juana, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ninfa Juana belongs to the “Mujeres en Acción” community bank. She lives in the Jr. 20 de mayo – Carretera Fernando B. Terry, in the San José de Sisa district, of the departament of San Martín. She is 43, married and has 3 children. Two of the children are still dependent upon her. She started with her first loan of 300 PEN, and with her own initiative she started her grocery business. She still has the same grocery store, located in her own house, where her main customers are community residents, neighbors, and friends. With a loan of 2,000 PEN, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy more products to stock her business. She will buy items like rice, bags of sugar, packages of milk, oil, personal hygiene supplies, house cleaning supplies, packs of soft drinks, and various other products to keep her customers happy. She is the one who makes decisions about the income from her business. Personally, she feels more independent, secure, and responsible about making her payments. Ninfa Juana is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businesswoman and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice,sacks of sugar, packages of milk,oil,products for personal hygiene,soft drinks.

loans.name: Dora

texts.es: La señora Dora, a sus 65 años, quedó viuda y junto a sus hijos y nietos pudo superar esta penosa pérdida, teniendo en ellos las fuerzas necesA. para seguir trabajando. A pesar de la nostalgia, trata de refugiarse en el trabajo y junto a su nieto mayor están implementando un restaurante en su domicilio, pues éste está ubicado en un lugar bastante transitado que hará próspero su negocio. Como prueba, primero instaló un pequeño puesto de comida en la puerta de su casa, el cual atiende todas las tardes desde las seis hasta la media noche y gracias a su buena sazón las personas han ido frecuentando su puesto de comida, lo cual animó a su nieto a poner en marcha los planes de negocio que tiene junto a su abuela. Ahora están a puertas de abrir su restaurante, donde las personas tendrán la posibilidad de visitar a doña Dora en su nuevo local, que estará en el mismo lugar, sólo que ahora podrán degustar tranquilamente de sus platillos preferidos, pues la atención será todo el día en un local más acogedor. Dora es socia fundadora de su grupo en MFP, y por seis años han compartido buenos momentos juntas, y su trabajo en equipo ha ido mejorando con el tiempo, pues han pasado por diversas dificultades económicas, por lo que han obtenido una valiosa experiencia. Los 3000 soles que ahora solicita están designados a la compra de materiales y utensilios necesarios para el pronto funcionamiento de su restaurante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dora, at 65 years of age, is widowed and together with her children and grandchildren was able to overcome this painful loss, finding in them the strength necessary to continue working. In spite of the nostalgia, she tries to take refuge in work and together with her oldest grandson she is setting up a restaurant in her home since it is located in a place with good traffic which will make for a prosperous business. As a test, she at first installed a small food stand in the door of her house which she attends every evening from 6pm until midnight and thanks to her good flavors the people are coming frequently to the food stand. This encouraged her grandson to put into motion plans for a business together with her. Now they are about to open their restaurant where people will have the possibility to visit Doña Dora in her new premises, which are in the same place, but now customers will be able to calmly eat their favorite dishes all day in a more comfortable setting.

Dora is a founding member of her group in MFP, and for six years they have shared good times together, and her teamwork has been improving with time. They have had diverse economic difficulties and have obtained valuable experience from them. The 3000 PEN that she is now asking for is designated to the purchase of materials and utensils necessary for the prompt start up of her restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of materials and utensils for her restaurant

loans.name: Kassim

texts.fr:
Natif de Koutiala, Kassim Dembélé est un polygame de  25 ans qui  vit avec ses femmes  et son enfant dans le quartier Kouloukoro de Koutiala ( Région de Sikasso ).
 Diplômé  en comptabilité (CAP) , Kassim n’a pas croisé les bras après les études. Il s’est  vite  intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce d’articles divers  il y’a de cela 3 ans. Il a appris cette activité auprès de sa grande sœur qui est vendeuse des tasses au grand marché de Koutiala. Il est très bien connu dans le secteur et reçoit  des commandes de diverses marchandises à travers des petits détaillants de la ville de koutiala. 
Pour pouvoir satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité, il a décidé de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et est à son premier prêt  individuel.  
Avec ce financement, il compte acheter  un important  stocks de marchandises à ACCRA  (la capitale du Ghana) et effectue sa vente sur son étale sis au grand marché  de Koutiala à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant ou à crédit.
Il compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 95.000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activités.
texts.en:
